summary: This tale comes from the papers of Diedrich Knickerbocker, a New York gentleman who researched Dutch colonial history by studying old families rather than books. He published a historically accurate work about Dutch governors before his death, and though critics question its literary merit, locals fondly remember him—even printing his likeness on cakes. The story proper introduces Rip Van Winkle, who lives in an ancient Dutch village at the foot of the mystical Kaatskill mountains during British colonial times. Rip is a simple, good-natured man beloved by village wives and children, but he's also a hen-pecked husband who avoids all profitable work on his own deteriorating farm while happily helping neighbors with theirs. His domineering wife Dame Van Winkle constantly berates him for his idleness and the family's declining fortunes, forcing Rip to seek refuge outside the house with his equally intimidated dog Wolf. As his marriage grows worse over the years, Rip increasingly escapes to a village club where local men gather at an inn under a portrait of King George III to discuss old news and gossip.

summary:
This tale comes from the papers of Diedrich Knickerbocker, a New York gentleman who researched Dutch colonial history. The story follows Rip Van Winkle, a simple, good-natured Dutch colonist living in an ancient village at the foot of the mystical Kaatskill mountains during British colonial times. Rip is beloved by villagers but hen-pecked by his domineering wife Dame Van Winkle, who constantly berates him for his idleness and their family's declining fortunes. To escape her criticism, Rip frequents the village inn where local men gather under Nicholas Vedder, the silent patriarch who communicates only through his pipe smoking patterns. When even this refuge is invaded by his wife's sharp tongue, Rip's only escape becomes wandering the woods with his sympathetic dog Wolf.

During one autumn hunting expedition high in the Kaatskill Mountains, Rip encounters a mysterious stranger in antique Dutch dress carrying a keg of liquor. Despite hearing his name called eerily through the mountains, Rip helps the strange man carry his burden through a ravine to a hidden amphitheater. There he discovers a company of odd-looking men in old Flemish clothing silently playing ninepins, their ball-rolling echoing like thunder through the mountains. After serving them drinks and sampling the excellent Holland gin himself, Rip falls into a deep sleep. Upon awakening on the mountain knoll the next morning, he finds his clean gun replaced by a rusted old firelock, Wolf missing, and his joints stiff with age.

Returning to his village, Rip discovers that twenty years have passed during his supernatural sleep. The mountain passage has vanished, replaced by an impassable waterfall. His beard has grown a foot long, and he finds his house in ruins, his wife apparently gone, and even a dog resembling Wolf no longer recognizes him. The village itself has transformed—the old Dutch inn is now "The Union Hotel," King George's portrait has been replaced by General Washington's, and the peaceful colonial atmosphere has given way to bustling political debate about elections, Congress, and liberty. When questioned by suspicious townspeople who mistake him for a political agitator, Rip learns that his old friends Nicholas Vedder, Brom Dutcher, and Van Bummel are dead, gone to war, or moved away. Most shocking of all, he encounters another man identified as "Rip Van Winkle"—apparently his own son, now grown to exactly resemble his father as he was twenty years ago. Confused and disoriented by these revelations, Rip can barely comprehend his own identity in this transformed world.

summary:
This tale comes from the papers of Diedrich Knickerbocker, a New York gentleman who researched Dutch colonial history. The story follows Rip Van Winkle, a simple, good-natured Dutch colonist living in an ancient village at the foot of the mystical Kaatskill mountains during British colonial times. Rip is beloved by villagers but hen-pecked by his domineering wife Dame Van Winkle, who constantly berates him for his idleness and their family's declining fortunes. To escape her criticism, Rip frequents the village inn where local men gather under Nicholas Vedder, the silent patriarch who communicates only through his pipe smoking patterns. When even this refuge is invaded by his wife's sharp tongue, Rip's only escape becomes wandering the woods with his sympathetic dog Wolf.

During one autumn hunting expedition high in the Kaatskill Mountains, Rip encounters a mysterious stranger in antique Dutch dress carrying a keg of liquor. Despite hearing his name called eerily through the mountains, Rip helps the strange man carry his burden through a ravine to a hidden amphitheater. There he discovers a company of odd-looking men in old Flemish clothing silently playing ninepins, their ball-rolling echoing like thunder through the mountains. After serving them drinks and sampling the excellent Holland gin himself, Rip falls into a deep sleep. Upon awakening on the mountain knoll the next morning, he finds his clean gun replaced by a rusted old firelock, Wolf missing, and his joints stiff with age.

Returning to his village after twenty years of supernatural sleep, Rip discovers a transformed world - the American Revolution has occurred, making him a free citizen instead of a British subject. Initially confused about his identity when confronted by suspicious townspeople and his own grown son, Rip's crisis is resolved when he reunites with his daughter Judith Gardenier and learns his domineering wife has died. An elderly villager, Peter Vanderdonk, validates Rip's supernatural experience by recounting local legends of Hendrick Hudson and his crew haunting the Kaatskills every twenty years. Now free from matrimonial tyranny and welcomed as a village patriarch, Rip resumes his idle habits, becoming a beloved storyteller who regales visitors with his incredible tale. The story concludes with Knickerbocker's authentication of these events and notes about the mythical traditions of the Catskill Mountains, including Indian legends of spirits and supernatural beings that have long inhabited the region.
